text: I suspect part of this is due to an aging population, but as @WilcoxNMP notes young adults aren't having sex like they used to either

text: Per the General Social Survey, the share of American adults who didn't have sex last year (23.2%) is the highest it's been in three decades of polling.

text: But perhaps the most concerning finding is this: unhealthy people are becoming much less happy. Suggests that it's much more difficult to be sick in America today than it was 20 years ago. Lots of potential reasons for this. https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2019/03/22/americans-are-getting-more-miserable-theres-data-prove-it/?utm_term=.a69c74c23012 …
author: _cingraham

text: There are some bright spots: the black-white happiness gap is narrowing, for instance. https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2019/03/22/americans-are-getting-more-miserable-theres-data-prove-it/?utm_term=.a69c74c23012 …
author: _cingraham

The bearded dragon said 'Now comes the subject I must broach:
These bugs are rare beyond compare when boiled, fried or poached;
But when it comes to scrumptiousness there's one beyond reproach:
The tasty crunch,
The tangy munch
Of this FANTASTIC ROACH'

text: The cost of free two-day shipping: average Amazon Air pilot makes 33% less than a FedEx or UPS pilot flying a similar plane at a similar level of experience. The Amazon Air pilots haven't had a raise in nearly a decade.
author: _cingraham

text: Amazon Air pilots told @rrpre that an accident was inevitable. Shortly thereafter an Amazon Air plane crashed, killing all three people on board. https://www.businessinsider.com/amazon-air-pilots-labor-issues-2019-2 …

text: Part of this kind of thinking is based on the fiction of "red states" and "blue states" -- the idea that states are politically uniform. But Trump got 4.5 million votes in California! And Clinton got 3.9 million in Texas!
author: _cingraham

text: You hear variations of this argument a lot, but California and New York combined account for just 15% of the country's population.
author: _cingraham

text: This dynamic isn't unique to the EC and I'm not sure what it says about the state of democracy when policies with broad support among voters and academic experts are routinely dismissed as impossible due to various structural forces and general legislative inertia.
author: _cingraham

text: The weird thing to me about the electoral college fight is that an idea with 60+% public support -- electing the president via popular vote -- is framed as an impossible fantasy right out of the gate.

text: Presumably. As I understand it the compact has a clause that prohibits states from leaving it, although I believe the enforceability of it is an open question.
author: _cingraham

text: One of the interesting things about the compact is that partisan support tends to ebb and flow depending on who's in the White House. Republicans were big on the idea during the Obama years, now Democrats are more interested. https://www.washingtonpost.com/us-policy/2019/03/19/elizabeth-warren-wants-abolish-electoral-college-heres-how-it-could-actually-happen-sort/?utm_term=.1d7f74657b90 …
author: _cingraham

text: Bills are currently under consideration in a number of states, including a few Democratic trifectas like Oregon, Maine and Nevada, where passage would seem to be a straightforward affair. https://www.washingtonpost.com/us-policy/2019/03/19/elizabeth-warren-wants-abolish-electoral-college-heres-how-it-could-actually-happen-sort/?utm_term=.1d7f74657b90 …
author: _cingraham

text: Strictly speaking you don't even need to abolish the Electoral College -- a national popular vote is just a few states away from becoming a reality. https://www.washingtonpost.com/us-policy/2019/03/19/elizabeth-warren-wants-abolish-electoral-college-heres-how-it-could-actually-happen-sort/?utm_term=.1d7f74657b90 …
author: _cingraham

text: In 2012, all 253 general election campaign events were held in just 12 states. 38 were ignored completely. In 2016, two-thirds of events were held in just 6 states. https://www.nationalpopularvote.com/written-explanation …
author: _cingraham

text: The other thing: check out the top ends of those distributions. Ceiling is *much* higher for elite grads. Top 10% of college grads make $84k. Top 10% of Ivy grads make *$205k* https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2019/03/16/operation-varsity-blues-data-shows-why-parents-might-take-risks-get-their-kids-right-college/?utm_term=.0e0520c1de31 …
author: _cingraham

text: If you're a wealthy, status-obsessed parent, you want your kid graduating with the $73k cohort, not with the unwashed $44k masses. Maybe even bad enough that you'd be willing to commit a felony to make it happen. https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2019/03/16/operation-varsity-blues-data-shows-why-parents-might-take-risks-get-their-kids-right-college/?utm_term=.0e0520c1de31 …
author: _cingraham

text: Is this necessarily because elite college kids are more talented or better educated? No. But it's a good indicator of the social and economic prestige that gets attached to degrees from these places. https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2019/03/16/operation-varsity-blues-data-shows-why-parents-might-take-risks-get-their-kids-right-college/?utm_term=.0e0520c1de31 …
author: _cingraham

text: The median graduate of a U.S. college could expect a salary of about $44,000 a decade after they first enrolled. For graduates of the eight colleges involved in last week's admissions scam, however, the median 10-year salary is $73,000. https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2019/03/16/operation-varsity-blues-data-shows-why-parents-might-take-risks-get-their-kids-right-college/?utm_term=.0e0520c1de31 …
